ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: - being able to identify verbs, nouns, adjectives, adverbs, etc. - felt comfortable enough with guessing what vocabulary might mean - learned how to use wordreference.com

I learned basic Spanish grammar and vocabulary, as well as how to skim a Spanish text for clues. Lessons were all very useful! Overall, this course gave me the skills I need to read Spanish materials while doing research.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: strength: - good size - good amount of practice translating individually and as a group - helpful assignments points for improvement: - slower and more comprehensive instruction at the beginning of the semester (especially considering that some people in the course knew no Spanish at the start of the course)
The class moves at a steady and manageable pace and the professor is very kind and always willing to help. No weaknesses!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would highly recommend this course to a beginning Spanish student whose most important goal is to read Spanish for research and brush up on grammar points.
Yes! It's a great way to learn the basics of the language for reading purposes.
Yes. I took this class to meet the language requirement and would recommend it to anyone who also needed to meet the requirement.
